title: Misconceptions about falling objects

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Both objects will hit the ground at the same time.

title: The lost art of democratic debate - Michael Sandel

multiple-choice.question: According to Aristotle, what is the essential nature of justice?

options.label: A
options.text: Giving people what they deserve based on their social status.

options.label: B
options.text: Giving people what they deserve based on their abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: Giving people what they deserve based on what they deserve.

options.label: D
options.text: Giving people what they deserve based on the purpose of the activity in question.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Supreme Court justices in the Casey Martin case wrestle with the question of what is the essential nature of golf?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they wanted to determine the fairness of the game.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they wanted to determine the athletic status of the game.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they wanted to determine the purpose of the game.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they wanted to determine the rules of the game.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the majority opinion and Justice Scalia's dissent in the Casey Martin case?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority opinion said that walking is essential to the game of golf, while Justice Scalia said it's not.

options.label: B
options.text: The majority opinion said that walking is not essential to the game of golf, while Justice Scalia said it is.

options.label: C
options.text: The majority opinion said that the purpose of the game of golf is to get a small ball into a hole, while Justice Scalia said it's to have fun.

options.label: D
options.text: The majority opinion said that the rules of the game are arbitrary, while Justice Scalia said they're essential.

multiple-choice.question: What is the underlying premise of the majority opinion in the Casey Martin case?

options.label: A
options.text: That the rules of the game are arbitrary and can be changed at will.

options.label: B
options.text: That the purpose of the game is to have fun and that walking is not essential.

options.label: C
options.text: That the essential nature of the game is to honor and recognize the excellence of the best players.

options.label: D
options.text: That the rules of the game are essential to the game itself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point that Michael Sandel is trying to make about the way we engage in democratic argument?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should shy away from moral questions in politics.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should engage directly with the moral convictions citizens bring to public life.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should require people to leave their deepest moral convictions outside politics.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should ignore the moral and religious convictions that people bring to public life.

multiple-choice.question: D: Giving people what they deserve based on the purpose of the activity in question.
C: Because they wanted to determine the purpose of the game.
B: The majority opinion said that walking is not essential to the game of golf, while Justice Scalia said it is.
C: That the essential nature of the game is to honor and recognize the excellence of the best players.
B: That we should engage directly with the moral convictions citizens bring to public life.

title: Your elusive creative genius - Elizabeth Gilbert

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main concern about being a writer, given their recent success with the book "Eat Pray Love"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are worried about losing their creative spark.

options.label: B
options.text: They are afraid of being unable to top their previous success.

options.label: C
options.text: They are concerned about the pressure to constantly produce bestsellers.

options.label: D
options.text: They are worried about the negative impact of their success on their mental health.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the traditional Western view of creativity, and how has it affected artists?

options.label: A
options.text: Creativity comes from a combination of human effort and divine inspiration, but the emphasis has shifted over time to focus more on human effort.

options.label: B
options.text: Creativity is solely the product of human effort and individual talent.

options.label: C
options.text: Creativity comes from a divine source, and artists are merely vessels for this creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: Creativity is a result of external influences, such as environment and upbringing.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker references the story of Ruth Stone, an American poet, who experienced a phenomenon where she would feel and hear poems coming to her from an external source. What was Stone's approach to dealing with this experience?

options.label: A
options.text: She tried to capture the poems by running to a piece of paper and a pencil as quickly as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: She would try to ignore the poems and focus on her daily life.

options.label: C
options.text: She would talk to the poems and ask them to come back at a more opportune moment.

options.label: D
options.text: She would try to write down the poems as they came to her, but often missed them.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions Tom Waits, an American musician, who had a similar experience with creative inspiration. How did Waits approach this experience?

options.label: A
options.text: He would try to capture the inspiration by writing it down immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: He would talk to the inspiration and ask it to come back at a more opportune moment.

options.label: C
options.text: He would acknowledge the inspiration and then let it go, recognizing that it was not under his control.

options.label: D
options.text: He would try to ignore the inspiration and focus on his daily life.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker references the concept of the "Divine cockeyed genius" and how it can affect artists. What is the speaker's main point about this concept?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker believes that the Divine cockeyed genius is a real entity that guides artists.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker thinks that the concept of the Divine cockeyed genius is outdated and no longer relevant.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker suggests that artists should try to tap into this external source of creativity, but acknowledges that it can be unpredictable and may not always be available.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker believes that the concept of the Divine cockeyed genius is a metaphor for the creative process, but not a literal entity.

title: Why do we see illusions? - Mark Changizi

multiple-choice.question: Why do we see the lines in the illusion as bowed outwards at their centers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brain has difficulty rendering simple images.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the lines are actually bowed outwards in real life.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brain perceives the lines as motion, and motion appears as bowing outwards.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the lines are too far away from us.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for our brain's slowness in perceiving the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brain is not complex enough.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain is too complex.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it takes a tenth of a second for our brain to process visual information.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brain is not evolved enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the optic blur cue in the illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the lines appear sharper.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the lines appear more parallel.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the lines appear as if they are moving.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the lines appear more distant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the brain's compensation for its slowness?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a best guess of the past.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a best guess of the present.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a best guess of the future.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a best guess of the environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the illusions being failed perceptions of the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are static images on the page.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not changing like in real life.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not perceived by our brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not seen by our eyes.
